channel.title: LinkedList remove method
channel.description:
For my java 2 college class we had to write our own implementation of a LinkedList. I can't write a remove method that seems to works. This is the only thing that isnt working in the program. I can give you all my code I just need you to write the remove method. You just pass it an index and it deletes the node at the index. I cant figure out how to unlink that node and then link the two parts of the list back together. If you are a java guru this shouldnt take you more than 20 minutes to figure out.
Due at 12CST its 8CST now. If you are interested im in IRC or pm me here, will be sent as a paypal gift when you can prove that it works.

item.title: LinkedList remove method
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

this is in c sharp, solution is same as java.

public void Delete(int i) { Node previous = null; Node current = head; while (current != null && current.data != i) { previous = current; current = current.link; } if (previous == null) { head = current.link; } else { previous.link = current.link; } –count; }

Read full topic

item.title: LinkedList remove method
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

This probably wont help but this is what my delete function looks like in c

struct cock *del(struct cock *root, int i) {
    if (i == 0) {
        struct cock *curr = root;
        free(root);
        curr = curr->next;
        root = curr;
        
    } else {
        struct cock *curr = root;
        int j;
        for (j = 0; j < i - 1; j++) {
            if (curr->next != NULL) {
                curr = curr->next;
            } else {
                break;
            }
        }
        free(curr->next);
        curr->next = curr->next->next;
    }
    return root;
}

Read full topic

item.title: LinkedList remove method
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Ha I agree, this was my UML,

I didnt have much to work with

firstNode : ListNode
lastNode : ListNode
numElements : int
name : String

<> LinkedList()
<> LinkedList(listName : String)

  • insertAtFront(item : E)
  • instertAtBack(item : E)
  • removeFromFront() : E throws EmptyListException
  • removeFromback() : E throws EmptyListException
  • remove(index : int) throws EmptyListException, IndexOutofBoundsException
  • get(index : int) : E throws EmptyListException, IndexOutofBoundsException
  • findAndRemove(item : E) : Boolean throws EmptyListException
  • findItem(item E) : int
  • lengthIs() : int
  • clear()
  • print()
  • isEmpty() : Boolean

Read full topic

item.title: LinkedList remove method
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:3, topic:421159”]Oh thanks for that. We had a list of specifications which made it a bit confusing but I figured it out almost immediately after posting using this

http://pages.cs.wisc.edu/~vernon/cs367/notes/4.LINKED-LIST.html

But my code was even a bit more confusing due to having to follow my teachers UML diagrams to dot.

Heres what I had to use

[code=java] public void remove(int index) throws EmptyListException, IndexOutOfBoundsException {
if(index<0 || index>numElements)
throw new IndexOutOfBoundsException(name);
if(numElements==0) {
throw new EmptyListException(name);
}
if(!isEmpty()) {
if(index == 0)
removeFromFront();
else{
ListNode tmp = FirstNode;

        while (tmp.getNext().getData() != get(index))
            tmp = tmp.getNext();
        tmp.setNext( tmp.getNext().getNext());
        numElements--;
        }
    }
}[/code]

Obviously the implementation we were forced to write is shit compared to the built in LinkedList library[/quote]
from a C perspective, i just vomited

Read full topic

item.title: LinkedList remove method
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Oh thanks for that. We had a list of specifications which made it a bit confusing but I figured it out almost immediately after posting using this

http://pages.cs.wisc.edu/~vernon/cs367/notes/4.LINKED-LIST.html

But my code was even a bit more confusing due to having to follow my teachers UML diagrams to dot.

Heres what I had to use

[code=java] public void remove(int index) throws EmptyListException, IndexOutOfBoundsException {
if(index<0 || index>numElements)
throw new IndexOutOfBoundsException(name);
if(numElements==0) {
throw new EmptyListException(name);
}
if(!isEmpty()) {
if(index == 0)
removeFromFront();
else{
ListNode tmp = FirstNode;

        while (tmp.getNext().getData() != get(index))
            tmp = tmp.getNext();
        tmp.setNext( tmp.getNext().getNext());
        numElements--;
        }
    }
}[/code]

Obviously the implementation we were forced to write is shit compared to the built in LinkedList library

Read full topic

item.title: LinkedList remove method
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

LinkedList:

public class List<T extends Node> {

	public final Node head;

	public List() {
		this.head = new Node();
		head.previous = head.next = head;
	}

	@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
	public T peek() {
		return (T) head.next;
	}

	@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
	public T peekLast() {
		return (T) head.previous;
	}

	@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
	public T pop() {
		Node node = head.next;
		if (node == head)
			return null;
		node.unlink();
		return (T) node;
	}

	@SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
	public T pollLast() {
		Node node = head.previous;
		if (node == head)
			return null;
		node.unlink();
		return (T) node;
	}

	public void push(Node node) {
		addAfter(head, node);
	}

	public void offer(Node node) {
		addBefore(head, node);
	}

	public boolean addAfter(Node node, Node add) {
		return addBefore(node.next, add);
	}

	public boolean addBefore(Node node, Node add) {
		if (contains(add))
			return false;
		(add.previous = node.previous).next = add;
		(add.next = node).previous = add;
		return true;
	}

	public boolean contains(Node node) {
		for (Node next = head.next; next != head; next = next.next)
			if (node == next || node.equals(next))
				return true;
		return false;
	}

	public boolean remove(Node node) {
		for (Node next = head.next; next != head; next = next.next)
			if (node == next) {
				node.unlink();
				return true;
			}
		return false;
	}

	public boolean isEmpty() {
		// return head.next == head;
		return size() == 0;
	}

	public void clear() {
		Node node = head.next;
		while (node != head) {
			Node next = node.next;
			node.next = node.previous = null;
			node = next;
		}
		head.next = head.previous = head;
	}

	public int size() {
		Node node = head.next;
		int count = 0;
		while (node != head) {
			node = node.next;
			count++;
		}
		return count;
	}
}

Node:

public class Node {

	public Node previous, next;
	public long identifier;

	public final void unlink() {
		if (next != null && previous != null) {
			previous.next = next;
			next.previous = previous;
		}
		this.next = this.previous = null;
	}
}

Derived from java.util.LinkedList

Edit: here’s a quick remove-by-index method, presuming you are iterating forward, and the node at index = 0 is the first non-head node in a nonempty list:

	public boolean remove(int index) {
		int count = 0;
		Node node = null;
		for (Node next = head.next; next != head; next = next.next) {
			if (count++ == index) {
				node = next;
				break;
			}
		}
		if (node == null)
			return false;
		node.unlink();
		return true;
	}

Read full topic
